1.brief: thou and thee, or (plural) ye and you
to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative
a dirge (as accompanied by beating the breasts or on instruments)
near, with or among; often in general, to
properly, an exalted one, i.e. a king or sheik; also a rising mist
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity

2.brief: properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))
to roar; a lion (properly, a lioness as the fiercer (although not a roarer;))
between (repeated before each noun, often with other particles); also as a conjunction, either...or
to crouch (on all four legs folded, like a recumbent animal); be implication, to recline, repose, brood, lurk, imbed
a bisection, i.e. (by implication) the centre
a village (as covered in by walls); also a young lion (perhaps as covered with a mane)
a cub (as still abiding in the lair), especially of the lion

3.brief: to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative
properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first
a cub (as still abiding in the lair), especially of the lion
a village (as covered in by walls); also a young lion (perhaps as covered with a mane)

properly, to goad, i.e. (by implication) to teach (the rod being an Oriental incentive)
to pluck off or pull to pieces; causatively to supply with food (as in morsels)
something torn, i.e. a fragment, e.g. a fresh leaf, prey, food
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)

near, with or among; often in general, to
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
a pit (especially as a trap); figuratively, destruction

a ring for the nose (or lips)

the earth (at large, or partitively a land)

a widow; also a desolate place
a city (a place guarded by waking or a watch) in the widest sense (even of a mere encampment or post)
to parch (through drought) i.e. (by analogy,) to desolate, destroy, kill
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
